title: AITA for being pissed off our dog sitter spent the entire weekend sleeping in my bedroom while my family & I were out town?
post:
So for the family vacation this year the lady who normally watches my kids for date nights offered to watch the dog this weekend so we did not have to board her. 

I noticed the garage door opener was offline so I began to check the camera to see if she was there so she could reset the breaker. In the process of checking the cameras I discovered that she has been taking food/drinks to my bedroom and sleeping there during the night and most of the day all weekend. 

Personally I have house/animal watched several times over the years and have NEVER slept/ate/drink in the owners bedroom. 

So now my question is AITA considering she does not live there and have just decided to do whatever they want?

Edit- additional info
*she was paid to watch the dog*

processed_comments.reasoning: Only asks a clarifying question about expectations; makes no claims about harm, intent, empathy, or apology. Minimal justification or principles but neutral and non-biased.
Seeks info about arrangements and sleeping plans without judging OP. Shows some ethical awareness about expectations; constructive and fair, with neutral language.
Asks whether OP specified staying and a room, no evaluative claims about OP. Reasonable focus on expectations; constructive, fair, and unbiased.

Calls the sitter’s behavior weird, implying inappropriate/harmful and intentional choice; no empathy or apology discussion. Gives a verdict but little reasoning; language is mildly judgmental but not biased.
Requests clarification about rules and sleeping space, no stance on OP’s character or harm. Shows some principle of communication; constructive and neutral.

Says OP is understandably bothered (mild harm) but not an AH and emphasizes need for clear communication, portraying OP as capable of empathy. Well-argued, cites norms about boundaries, balanced and respectful.
Describes situation as weird but rooted in mutual assumptions, implying some minor harm but no strong blame. Reasoning is brief but references communication; tone is neutral and unbiased.
Expresses shock about food/drink in bedroom, implying it’s a problem but without elaboration on intent or empathy. Very little justification or principle; somewhat reactive but not identity-biased.
Labels OP NTA and sitter’s behavior as outrageous, implying intentional boundary violation and harm. Minimal explanation; tone is reactive but not slur-based.

Calls OP YTA for being pissed, but frames harm as minor and focuses on ambiguity and norms of dog sitting. Strong, detailed justification and principles (clarity, proportionality); firm yet generally respectful and unbiased.

Says NAH and stresses OP’s vague arrangement, implying issue is miscommunication more than serious harm. Well-justified, appeals to norms of pet-sitting and clarity; critical but fair and neutral in language.
Asks for more detail on expectations and permissions, no claims about OP’s morality or harm. Shows some awareness of consent/boundaries; constructive and unbiased.

Assumes sitter was only to check in, calls using master suite wrong and suggests conditions for future payment, implying harm and deliberate overstep and need for correction. Some justification but also assumptions; somewhat unfairly one-sided though language avoids slurs.

States sleeping in someone’s bedroom is wrong and couch should be used, implying intentional boundary violation and harm. Limited reasoning and no nuance; language is judgmental but not identity-biased.
Calls OP YTA but frames sitter’s behavior as normal for dogsitting, not harmful or malicious. Provides clear justification and norms; tone is firm but reasoned and unbiased.
Says OP is YTA only absent specific instructions, focusing on lack of explicit limits rather than harm or intent. Reasoning is concise but principle-based (clear expectations); neutral language.

Labels it a mutual communication error, acknowledging OP’s feelings but not serious wrongdoing and suggesting future clarity, implying OP can be understanding. Good explanation of norms; balanced and respectful.
Offers conditional verdicts based on whether she was staying, tying blame to clarity of expectations, not harm or intent. Well-reasoned, principle-focused, and neutral.

Calls OP YTA for not setting parameters and expecting mind-reading, focusing on responsibility for clear instructions rather than harm. Strong justification and principle of autonomy/clarity; tone is sharp but not biased.

Says ESH, blaming OP for unclear expectations and sitter for presumptuous eating in bedroom, implying some harm and intentional overstep by sitter. Balanced blame with clear principles about employer responsibility and boundaries; respectful and unbiased.

Comment says OP is wrong for being upset because they failed to set expectations, implying sitter was harmed by unfair anger and OP knowingly didn’t clarify. It gives clear reasoning, references norms of pet sitting, is respectful, proportionate, and uses neutral language.

Comment asks for clarification and does not assert harm, intent, empathy, or apology about OP. It’s brief but constructive, invokes the importance of explicit agreements, is fair and neutral in tone and language.

Comment claims OP is dodging questions and knows they’re wrong, implying deliberate blame-shifting and unfairness toward sitter. It justifies verdict with specific details and principles of communication, but tone is somewhat accusatory though not identity-biased.

Comment says OP failed to set things up clearly and sitter disrespected personal space, so both caused harm and OP’s failure was avoidable. It articulates distinctions between dog- vs house-sitting and respect for privacy, is balanced and civil, and uses unbiased language.

Comment focuses on general etiquette about bedrooms and suggests clearer instructions next time, without judging OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It gives some reasoning and advice, is fair and respectful, and uses neutral language.

Comment says dogs need company and OP is at fault for unclear expectations, implying sitter was wronged and OP’s failure was avoidable. It explains pet-sitting norms and communication duties, is constructive and proportionate, and uses unbiased language.

Comment shares professional experience and asks if OP discussed sleeping arrangements, without assigning clear blame or mental states. It articulates norms (sleep where told), is highly deliberative and fair, and uses neutral language.

Comment calls sitter’s behavior a breach of privacy and asks about payment and instructions, implying OP was harmed but not focusing on OP’s intent or empathy. It gives some justification and privacy principle, is somewhat one-sided but not hostile or biased.

Comment speculates about sitter’s belief based on whether sheets were washed, without claims about OP’s mindset or harm. It offers a narrow inference with minimal ethical framing, is neutral and non-hostile, and uses unbiased language.

Comment leans YTA, suggesting OP’s anger is misplaced given common practice and unclear expectations, implying sitter is unfairly blamed. It explains a contrasting long-term arrangement and notes confusion, but is somewhat muddled on verdict while remaining fair and neutral in language.

Comment says OP failed to clarify expectations and sitter disrespected the bedroom, so both caused issues and OP’s failure was avoidable. It clearly states reasons and norms about communication and respect for space, is balanced, and uses neutral language.
Comment only asks if OP showed the sitter a bedroom, without attributing harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It’s minimal but constructive, fair, and uses neutral language.

Comment says there’s confusion on both sides and OP isn’t in a strong position to be upset, implying OP’s reaction risks unfair harm but also urging benefit of the doubt and understanding. It articulates misunderstanding and need for clear agreements, is very constructive and fair, and uses unbiased language.

Comment says YTA because dog-sitting usually means staying over unless explicitly limited, implying sitter was harmed by OP’s unspoken expectations. It explains norms and cost considerations, is reasoned and proportionate, and uses neutral language.

Comment calls owner’s bedroom a no-go and questions letting unrelated people access your house, implying sitter’s actions were harmful and OP is justified. Justification is brief and somewhat absolutist, tone is a bit judgmental toward the practice, and language is mostly neutral but slightly loaded.

Comment asserts anyone would be mad and insults other commenters as weirdos, implying sitter’s behavior was harmful and OP justified. It offers little structured reasoning, uses dismissive and insulting language, and shows low deliberative quality and fairness.

Comment concludes NAH and calls it a misunderstanding, implying OP is reasonably empathetic and no real blame. It briefly references having read OP’s comments, is conciliatory and fair, and uses neutral language.

Comment says YTA, expecting sitter to hang out with the dog and criticizing OP for assuming mind-reading, implying sitter was harmed by unfair expectations. It mentions need for explicit expectations, is somewhat admonishing but not hostile, and uses unbiased language.

Comment shares a personal anecdote about a sitter staying and drinking vodka, without judging OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It’s tangential with limited ethical analysis but neutral and non-hostile.

Comment says NTA if OP specified only brief visits, calling the sitter’s actions invasive and asking about camera awareness, implying harm to OP and sitter’s responsibility. It distinguishes job types and privacy, is reasoned and proportionate, and uses neutral language.

Comment focuses on harm to the dog (neglect) and shared blame, not on OP’s intent, empathy, or apology. It briefly justifies ESH with animal-care norms but is shallow on principles and proportionality.

Comment says OP expected neglectful care and implies deliberate disregard for proper dog care, with no empathy or apology. It clearly explains why dog sitters stay over, invokes animal welfare, and is firm but reasoned and non-biased.

Comment blames OP for not communicating expectations, implying OP is at fault but not focusing on harm or empathy. Reasoning is brief but ties verdict to communication norms and uses neutral language.

Comment implies there is harm/violation in eating in someone else’s bedroom but doesn’t discuss intent, empathy, or apology. It questions other judgments but gives little structured argument or principle articulation.

Comment highlights hygiene-related harm and also notes dog neglect, but doesn’t address OP’s intent or empathy. It articulates norms about consent, cleanliness, and dog care, though tone is somewhat harsh and insulting.

Comment treats this as miscommunication without clear harm or intent and suggests no one is an AH, recommending clearer expectations next time. It gives moderate justification, references boundary-setting, and is calm and fair.

Comment says OP is wrong due to lack of communication and that sitter’s behavior is normal, implying OP knowingly failed to set expectations and is overreacting. It clearly explains norms of dog sitting and uses respectful, neutral language.

Comment suggests OP didn’t communicate expectations and contrasts with their own empathetic approach to dog care, implying OP is less considerate but not an AH. It discusses dog’s emotional needs and miscommunication in a balanced, respectful way.
Comment doesn’t directly judge OP’s character but models clear boundary-setting as best practice. It implicitly references consent and communication norms and is constructive and neutral.
Comment frames situation as miscommunication without emphasizing harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It explains typical dog-sitting expectations and is even-handed and respectful.
Comment assigns blame to both for unclear expectations and to sitter for eating in bed, implying a boundary violation but not intent or empathy. It briefly states reasons and is neutral in language.
Comment only asks for more information about a spare room and makes no claims about harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It is neutral, minimally justificatory, and non-biased.

Comment supports OP as NTA and describes sitter’s actions as breaking trust and invading space, implying harm but not focusing on intent or empathy. It articulates norms about consent and boundaries, though tone is somewhat judgmental toward others.
Short comment just states a norm about pet sitters staying over, without discussing harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It offers almost no justification or ethical framing but is neutral in language.
Comment says eating in someone else’s bed is unacceptable and would justify OP’s anger, implying a boundary harm. It briefly explains this norm and uses clear but non-biased language.

Comment calls OP YTA for poor communication and expecting inadequate dog care, implying intentional neglect of norms and harm to dog’s welfare. It clearly articulates expectations, consent around cameras, and is firm yet neutral in wording.

Comment describes their own arrangement as a model and doesn’t directly assess OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It implicitly references fairness to sitter and dog’s need for company, in a constructive, neutral tone.

Comment says OP is TA for not communicating and for thinking twice-daily visits suffice, calling that neglect, thus implying harm and knowing failure. It clearly ties verdict to responsibility and animal welfare and uses strong but non-biased language.

Comment frames OP as employer responsible for setting expectations, implying blame but not explicit harm or empathy discussion. It appeals to role-based responsibility and is concise, fair, and neutral.

Comment blames OP for not discussing expectations and expecting mind-reading, focusing on intent to the extent of responsibility. It references norms of clear communication and is respectful and unbiased.
Comment shares a contrasting anecdote and does not directly assess OP’s harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It gives minimal argument or principles but is polite and unbiased.

Comment is ambivalent and asks clarifying questions rather than judging OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It references comfort and communication norms, is respectful, and considers multiple angles.

Comment says sitter “sucks” for going into bedroom (implying intentional boundary violation and harm) and faults OP for vagueness, implying OP lacked empathy and repair. It clearly justifies ESH with reference to expectations and boundaries, in a mostly fair and neutral tone.

Comment calls sitter’s behavior a “huge boundary violation” (harm and intentionality) and notes OP’s partial fault and need to set rules, implying OP should correct and effectively apologize via boundaries. It articulates norms about privacy, communication, and offers constructive advice while remaining behavior-focused.

Comment labels OP YTA for not setting expectations and being mad, implying OP knowingly failed to communicate but doesn’t stress concrete harm. It strongly justifies its stance with detailed examples and norms about communication and pet care, in a respectful, unbiased way.

Comment states a norm that dog sitting implies overnight stay and bed use, without directly judging OP’s empathy, intent, harm, or apology. It gives some justification and principle (expectation clarity) in neutral language.

Comment simply says owners usually tell sitter which room and concludes YTA, without explicit claims about harm, intent, empathy, or apology. Justification and principles are minimal but tone is neutral and unbiased.
Comment says NAH unless OP explicitly forbade bedroom use, not specifying harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It briefly references conditional blame and is neutral and non-hostile.
This is a duplicate NAH comment with same conditional reasoning, again not addressing harm, intent, empathy, or apology. Argument and principles are brief but fair and unbiased.

Comment leans toward OP being at fault for vague arrangements but doesn’t explicitly discuss harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It notes standard sitter practice and learning from experience, showing some ethical reasoning and constructive tone.
Comment only asks for INFO about another bed, so it doesn’t attribute harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It lacks justification or principles but is neutral and respectful.
Single-word “YTA” gives no detail on harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It has no justification or principles and is minimally deliberative, though not overtly biased.

Comment blames OP for not setting expectations and then being mad, implying OP knowingly failed to communicate but not emphasizing harm or empathy. It briefly references responsibility and judgment, in neutral language.

Comment says it’s weird but not a big deal and suggests washing sheets, implying some boundary issue but downplaying harm and not discussing empathy or apology. Justification is light and tone is casual but non-hostile.

Comment assigns NAH and focuses on mutual lack of clarity, not framing OP as harmful, intentional, empathetic, or apologetic. It clearly discusses rules, trust, and boundaries, with balanced blame and respectful language.

Comment calls OP’s reaction “super weird” and YTA for not telling sitter where to sleep, implying OP knowingly failed to communicate but not focusing on harm or empathy. It references common dog-sitting norms but uses mildly dismissive language.

Comment lists three reasons OP is YTA, including lack of agreement, leaving dog alone, and undisclosed cameras, implying OP’s intentional negligence and harm to both sitter and dog. It articulates clear ethical norms about communication, animal welfare, and privacy, with strong justification and only mildly sharp tone.
Comment asks detailed INFO about where OP told sitter to sleep and expectations, without judging harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It highlights communication norms and is constructive and neutral.

Comment queries whether this was housesitting and notes that staying over is normal, without attributing harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It offers a brief norm-based perspective in neutral language.

Comment asks if sitter knows about being filmed and mentions a lawsuit, not directly judging OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It hints at privacy norms with minimal argument but remains neutral and unbiased.

Comment says OP is overreacting to harmless, normal sitter behavior, implying OP is intentionally making a big deal and lacking empathy, with no mention of apology. It clearly explains norms for sitters, references details, and is reasonably respectful and unbiased though somewhat dismissive.
Comment blames OP for poor communication but gives no detail about harm, empathy, or apology. It offers almost no justification or ethical framing, is curt and mildly insulting, but not biased.

Comment just shares personal experience of sitters sleeping in the bedroom without directly judging OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It weakly implies a norm, is neutral and respectful, but light on explicit argument or principles.

Comment implies there was no real harm beyond dirty sheets and that OP is wrong to be upset, with no empathy or apology discussion. It gives a brief practical suggestion, minimal reasoning, somewhat dismissive tone but not biased.

Comment sees some harm/unprofessionalism and mutual responsibility, implying OP should clarify boundaries and that repair/communication is needed. It articulates norms about sitters, cameras, and eating in bed, is balanced and respectful, and avoids biased language.

Comment treats OP as clearly at fault, emphasizing OP’s nondisclosure of cameras and expectations as intentional AH behavior causing a privacy/harm issue. It gives detailed justification, clear ethical norms (disclosure, expectations, dog care), is firm but mostly respectful and unbiased.
Comment doesn’t assign clear blame or discuss harm/empathy/apology, instead asks for clarification. It notes common expectations for sitters, is constructive and fair, and uses neutral language.

Comment asserts OP is at fault for vague instructions and overreacting, implying OP is intentionally blaming sitter for normal behavior and not empathetic. It explains sitter norms and boundary-setting, is fairly reasoned and proportionate, and uses nonbiased language.
